channel.title: Commands problem
channel.description: is it possible that the admin can use all the commands that the regular player can use and the mod can use ...ive noticed that i cant use a command that a regular player can or a mod can use i have to have the right as a player to do a normal command is there a way i can change this

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:9, topic:538184”]So I re-wrote some of the class. is this better?

[code=java]**

  • CommandManager
  • January 6, 2014
  • Dan0194
    */
    package org.hyperion.rs2.model.command;

import org.hyperion.rs2.model.Player;

public class CommandManager {

/**
 *Setter for our class 
 */
private static CommandManager commandManager = new CommandManager();

/**
 * Loops through our enum to check if they have the correct
 * rights to execute that class with the commands
 * finds the class via String name and makes a new instance out of it
 * calls our handle command method
 */
public CommandManager getCommand(Player player, String command, String args[]) {
	for(CommandRights c : CommandRights.values()) {
		if(player.getRights().toInteger() >= c.getRights()) {
			CommandHandler commandHandler = c.getCommandHandler();
			commandHandler.handleCommand(player, command, args);
		}
	}
	return this;
}

private static enum CommandRights {
	/**
	 * If they are normal player
	 */
	NORMAL(0, new NormalCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are moderator, normal player
	 */
	MODERATOR(1, new ModeratorCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are a admin, moderator or normal player
	 */
	ADMIN(2, new AdminCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are a owner, admin, moderator or normal player
	 */
	OWNER(3, new OwnerCommands());
	
	/**
	 * rights they have to be
	 */
	private int rights;
	/**
	 * Type of commandhandler
	 */
	private CommandHandler commandHandler;
	
	/**
	 * Constructer
	 * @param rights
	 * @param commandHandler
	 */
	CommandRights(int rights, CommandHandler commandHandler) {
		this.rights = rights;
		this.commandHandler = commandHandler;
	}
	
	/**
	 * @return rights
	 */
	public int getRights() {
		return rights;
	}
	
	/**
	 * @return commandHandler
	 */
	public CommandHandler getCommandHandler() {
		return commandHandler;
	}
}

/**
 * @return commandManager
 */
public static CommandManager getCommandManager() {
	return commandManager;
}

}[/code]

I knew I fudgeed up on the enum.[/quote]
yeah

Read full topic

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:7, topic:538184”][quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=657009.msg4395546#msg4395546 date=1388991105]
You can also make an interface to seperate the moderator, normal, admin, owner commands.

So for example if you made a new class named CommandHandler and put this inside

[code=java]public interface CommandHandler {

/**
 * handles all the commands
 */
void handleCommand(Player player, String command);

}[/code]

And then make a new class named like NormalCommands

And put this inside

[code=java]public class NormalCommands implements CommandHandler {

@Override
public void handleCommand(Player player, String command) {
	//All commands
}

}[/code]

And then make a class to manage your commands so put this in

[code=java]public class CommandManager {

            private enum CommandRights {
	NORMAL(0, "NormalCommands"),
	MODERATOR(1, "ModeratorCommands"),
	ADMIN(2, "AdminCommands");
            OWNER(3, "OwnerCommands");
	
	private int rights;
	private String object;
	
	private CommandRights(int rights, String object) {
		this.object = object;
		this.rights = rights;
	}
	
	public String getObject() {
		return object;
	}
	
	public int getRights() {
		return rights;
	}
	
}

    private static CommandsManager commandsManager = new CommandsManager();

public CommandManager getCommand(Player player, String command)  {
	for(CommandRights c : CommandRights.values()) {
		if(player.getRight() <= c.getRights()) {
			Class<?> handleObject = Class.forName(c.getObject());
			Object handleInstance = handleObject.newInstance();
			CommandHandler command = (CommandHandler) handleInstance;
		        command.handleCommand(player, command);
			}
                     return this;
		}

                    public CommandManager getCommandManager() {
                    return commandManager;
                  }
	}[/code]

And then whereever you handle your packet for commands put

You would have to make the classes for AdminCommands, OwnerCommands and ModeratorCommands and just follow the same guideline I used for NormalCommands.

You obviously don’t need to do this but it would be a lot better and cleaner.
[/quote]
What the hell? you could have just used CommandHandler as a parameter in the enum. A lot of that is completely uneccessary, and would not perform well.[/quote]
So I re-wrote some of the class. is this better?

[code=java]**

  • CommandManager
  • January 6, 2014
  • Dan0194
    */
    package org.hyperion.rs2.model.command;

import org.hyperion.rs2.model.Player;

public class CommandManager {

/**
 *Setter for our class 
 */
private static CommandManager commandManager = new CommandManager();

/**
 * Loops through our enum to check if they have the correct
 * rights to execute that class with the commands
 * finds the class via String name and makes a new instance out of it
 * calls our handle command method
 */
public CommandManager getCommand(Player player, String command, String args[]) {
	for(CommandRights c : CommandRights.values()) {
		if(player.getRights().toInteger() >= c.getRights()) {
			CommandHandler commandHandler = c.getCommandHandler();
			commandHandler.handleCommand(player, command, args);
		}
	}
	return this;
}

private static enum CommandRights {
	/**
	 * If they are normal player
	 */
	NORMAL(0, new NormalCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are moderator, normal player
	 */
	MODERATOR(1, new ModeratorCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are a admin, moderator or normal player
	 */
	ADMIN(2, new AdminCommands()),
	/**
	 * If they are a owner, admin, moderator or normal player
	 */
	OWNER(3, new OwnerCommands());
	
	/**
	 * rights they have to be
	 */
	private int rights;
	/**
	 * Type of commandhandler
	 */
	private CommandHandler commandHandler;
	
	/**
	 * Constructer
	 * @param rights
	 * @param commandHandler
	 */
	CommandRights(int rights, CommandHandler commandHandler) {
		this.rights = rights;
		this.commandHandler = commandHandler;
	}
	
	/**
	 * @return rights
	 */
	public int getRights() {
		return rights;
	}
	
	/**
	 * @return commandHandler
	 */
	public CommandHandler getCommandHandler() {
		return commandHandler;
	}
}

/**
 * @return commandManager
 */
public static CommandManager getCommandManager() {
	return commandManager;
}

}[/code]

I knew I fucked up on the enum.

Read full topic

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:4, topic:538184”]You can also make an interface to seperate the moderator, normal, admin, owner commands.

So for example if you made a new class named CommandHandler and put this inside

[code=java]public interface CommandHandler {

/**
 * handles all the commands
 */
void handleCommand(Player player, String command);

}[/code]

And then make a new class named like NormalCommands

And put this inside

[code=java]public class NormalCommands implements CommandHandler {

@Override
public void handleCommand(Player player, String command) {
	//All commands
}

}[/code]

And then make a class to manage your commands so put this in

[code=java]public class CommandManager {

            private enum CommandRights {
	NORMAL(0, "NormalCommands"),
	MODERATOR(1, "ModeratorCommands"),
	ADMIN(2, "AdminCommands");
            OWNER(3, "OwnerCommands");
	
	private int rights;
	private String object;
	
	private CommandRights(int rights, String object) {
		this.object = object;
		this.rights = rights;
	}
	
	public String getObject() {
		return object;
	}
	
	public int getRights() {
		return rights;
	}
	
}

    private static CommandsManager commandsManager = new CommandsManager();

public CommandManager getCommand(Player player, String command) throws ClassNotFoundException, InstantiationException, IllegalAccessException  {
	for(CommandRights c : CommandRights.values()) {
		if(player.getRight() <= c.getRights()) {
			Class<?> handleObject = Class.forName(c.getObject());
			Object handleInstance = handleObject.newInstance();
			CommandHandler command = (CommandHandler) handleInstance;
		        command.handleCommand(player, command);
			}
                     return this;
		}

                    public CommandManager getCommandManager() {
                    return commandManager;
                  }
	}[/code]

And then whereever you handle your packet for commands put

You would have to make the classes for AdminCommands, OwnerCommands and ModeratorCommands and just follow the same guideline I used for NormalCommands.

You obviously don’t need to do this but it would be a lot better and cleaner.[/quote]
What the hell? you could have just used CommandHandler as a parameter in the enum. A lot of that is completely uneccessary, and would not perform well.

Read full topic

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“holylouis, post:5, topic:538184”]i think ill go this route bc it does seem alot more effenient and cleaner

also can u give me what a command should look like in this? soo ill be able to adjust my commands[/quote]
It would look pretty much the same.

if(command.equals("test")) { player.sendMessage("It works."); }

By the way you are going to need to adjust some variables to make it work for your server.

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

You can also make an interface to seperate the moderator, normal, admin, owner commands.

So for example if you made a new class named CommandHandler and put this inside

[code=java]public interface CommandHandler {

/**
 * handles all the commands
 */
void handleCommand(Player player, String command);

}[/code]

And then make a new class named like NormalCommands

And put this inside

[code=java]public class NormalCommands implements CommandHandler {

@Override
public void handleCommand(Player player, String command) {
	//All commands
}

}[/code]

And then make a class to manage your commands so put this in

[code=java]public class CommandManager {

            private enum CommandRights {
	NORMAL(0, "NormalCommands"),
	MODERATOR(1, "ModeratorCommands"),
	ADMIN(2, "AdminCommands");
            OWNER(3, "OwnerCommands");
	
	private int rights;
	private String object;
	
	private CommandRights(int rights, String object) {
		this.object = object;
		this.rights = rights;
	}
	
	public String getObject() {
		return object;
	}
	
	public int getRights() {
		return rights;
	}
	
}

    private static CommandsManager commandsManager = new CommandsManager();

public CommandManager getCommand(Player player, String command) throws ClassNotFoundException, InstantiationException, IllegalAccessException  {
	for(CommandRights c : CommandRights.values()) {
		if(player.getRight() <= c.getRights()) {
			Class<?> handleObject = Class.forName(c.getObject());
			Object handleInstance = handleObject.newInstance();
			CommandHandler command = (CommandHandler) handleInstance;
		        command.handleCommand(player, command);
			}
                     return this;
		}

                    public CommandManager getCommandManager() {
                    return commandManager;
                  }
	}[/code]

And then whereever you handle your packet for commands put

You would have to make the classes for AdminCommands, OwnerCommands and ModeratorCommands and just follow the same guideline I used for NormalCommands.

You obviously don’t need to do this but it would be a lot better and cleaner.

Read full topic

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @holylouis holylouis
item.description:
@holylouis wrote:

thank you soo much man youve helped me soo much and that means i got alot of recoding to do in my commands list

this is what most of the commands look like

	if (command[0].startsWith("pfplayer")) {
		long start = System.nanoTime();
		long start2 = System.currentTimeMillis();
		World.getWorld().doPath(new DefaultPathFinder(), player,
				Integer.parseInt(command[1]), Integer.parseInt(command[2]));
		long end = System.nanoTime();
		long end2 = System.currentTimeMillis();
		System.out.println((end - start) + ", " + (end2 - start2));
	}
	if (command[0].equals("itemoninter")) {
		ActionSender.sendInterfaceConfig(player,
				Integer.parseInt(command[1]), Integer.parseInt(command[2]),
				true);
		ActionSender.sendItemOnInterface(player,
				Integer.parseInt(command[1]), Integer.parseInt(command[2]),
				100, 4151);
	}
	if (command[0].equals("stringtest")) {
		int interfaceid = Integer.parseInt(command[1]);
		int childid = Integer.parseInt(command[2]);
		for (int i = 0; i < childid; i++) {

			// ActionSender.sendInterfaceConfig(player,
			// Integer.parseInt(command[1]), i, true);
			ActionSender.sendString(player, interfaceid, i, "" + i);

			player.sendMessage("Interface: " + interfaceid + " ID: " + i);
		}
	}

	if (command[0].equals("sstring")) {
		// for (int i = 0; i < 318; i++) {
		// ActionSender.sendInterfaceConfig(player,
		// Integer.parseInt(command[1]), i,ol true);
		ActionSender.sendSpecialString(player,
				Integer.parseInt(command[1]), "WEEEEE");
		// }
	}
	if (command[0].equals("bconfigtest")) {
		for (int i = Integer.parseInt(command[1]); i < Integer
				.parseInt(command[2]); i++) {
			ActionSender.sendBConfig(player, i, 0);
		}
	}
	if (command[0].equals("bconfig")) {
		ActionSender.sendBConfig(player, Integer.parseInt(command[1]),
				Integer.parseInt(command[2]));
	}
	if (command[0].equals("configtest")) {
		for (int i = Integer.parseInt(command[1]); i < Integer
				.parseInt(command[2]); i++) {
			ActionSender.sendConfig(player, i, 4);
		}
	}
	if (command[0].equals("logout")) {
		ActionSender.sendLogout(player, 5);
	}
	/*
	 * if (command[0].equals("nexdmg")) { Nex nex =
	 * NexAreaEvent.getNexAreaEvent().getNex();
	 * nex.getDamageManager().damage(player, Integer.parseInt(command[1]),
	 * 1, DamageType.RED_DAMAGE); }
	 */

	if (command[0].equals("grounditemaddtest")) {
		ArrayList<Location> locations = new ArrayList<Location>();
		for (int x = player.getLocation().getX() - 30; x < player
				.getLocation().getX() + 30; x++) {
			for (int y = player.getLocation().getY() - 30; y < player
					.getLocation().getY() + 30; y++) {
				locations.add(Location.locate(x, y, 0));
			}
		}
		long old = System.currentTimeMillis();
		for (Location l : locations) {
			GroundItemManager.createGroundItem(new GroundItem(player,
					new Item(4151, 1), l, false));
		}
		System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis() - old);
	}
	if (command[0].equals("grounditemremovetest")) {
		int rev = 0;
		long old = System.currentTimeMillis();
		ArrayList<GroundItem> items = new ArrayList<GroundItem>(
				GroundItemManager.getGroundItems());
		for (GroundItem groundItem : items) {
			GroundItemManager.removeGroundItem(groundItem);
			rev++;

item.title: Commands problem
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Make it so that when the players right is equal to or greater than the rank you want like

if(command.equalsIgnoreCase(“tele”) && player.getRank() >= 1) {
//item command
}
